subject: Re: [junit] @Before vs constructor
msgSnippet: ... There s still global state, filesystems, etc. ... Two answers: 1) Many, because I like taking advantage of, for example, initialization in field
messageBody:
On Thu, Oct 23, 2008 at 10:20 AM, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> On Thu, Oct 23, 2008 at 2:20 AM, Joakim Ohlrogge
> <joakim.ohlrogge@...> wrote:
>>
>> I think that there would be some unhappy JUnit users out there if we
>> got one instance shared between all tests in the class. The reason is
>> that JUnit tests have always been isolated an we have come to expect
>> that to be the case. It is quite convenient not to have to worry about
>> restoring state between testruns so that testB can never fail because
>> testA failed to clean after iteself
>
> But if this were the case, @After would be pointless, wouldn't it?

There's still global state, filesystems, etc.

> How many of your tests would suddenly break if instances were shared?

Two answers:

1) Many, because I like taking advantage of, for example,
initialization in field declarations.

2) Lately, I'm of the opinion that forcing developers to make this
decision on a per-test basis is a waste of human development, just
like manual register allocation. The tool should run the test as
written, and can optimize by, for example, sharing instances. I'm not
aware of a tool that does this. Yet.

David Saff
